Name: Fentrazamide
Description: Fentrazamide is a member of tetrazoles.

plant_translocations.content: A research conducted by Goto et al. in 2002 explored the efficacy of 1-phenyl-5(4H)-4-dialkylcarbamoyltetrazolinones as herbicides for controlling barnyardgrass (Echinochloa spp.) in paddy rice cultivation. Among these compounds, fentrazamide, 4-(2-chlorophenyl)-N-cyclohexyl-N-ethyl-4,5-dihydro-5-oxo-1H-tetrazole-1-carboxamide, stood out as a promising rice paddy herbicide. Fentrazamide demonstrated excellent efficacy against barnyardgrass, being applied during rice transplantation due to its prolonged residual activity in Japan and Korea. The study investigated the translocation of 14C-fentrazamide from treated roots to shoots in both rice and early watergrass. Over the course of 7 days, the translocation increased in both species, with rice exhibiting significantly higher translocation rates compared to early watergrass. The radioactivity per plant was substantially greater in rice, both in roots and shoots, while early watergrass showed higher relative percentages of absorbed radioactivity. This research indicates that fentrazamide is a systemic herbicide, demonstrating notable effectiveness in controlling barnyardgrass in paddy rice fields.
plant_translocations.reference: Lim, S. J., Sunohara, Y., & Matsumoto, H. (2008). Absorption, translocation, and metabolism of fentrazamide in rice and early watergrass (Echinochloa oryzicola). Weed Biology & Management, 8(3).

method.Plant Growth Condition: Seeds soaked in water at 30°C for 2 days, then germinated in 1/4 strength modified Kasugai's nutrient solution in growth chamber at 25/20°C day/night for 1 day in dark. Seedlings further grown for 7 days to second leaf stage at 25/20°C, 12 h photoperiod, ~400 μmol/m2/s light intensity.
method.Chemical Preparation: 14C-fentrazamide with 1.3 GBq/mmol specific activity used at 260.1 kBq radioactivity.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Absorption and distribution - roots immersed in 14C-fentrazamide solution for 6, 12, 24 h. 10 plants per replication, 3 replicates.
method.Other Information: After treatment, plants harvested and separated into roots and shoots. Dried at 90°C for 24 h. 14C radioactivity measured by liquid scintillation counting after sample oxidation. Results expressed as % of total absorbed and DPM/g fresh weight.
